28. In ‘‘Compensation,’’ Emerson casts the problem as the soul’s response to nature’s unequal dispensation of abilities, opportunities, and fortunes among people—the differences between ‘‘Less’’ and ‘‘More.’’ Death and calamity are constants of the cycle of life—Emerson calls it ‘‘growth’’—that force each of us to adapt, cope, and keep moving forward
Taylor’s use of the narrative language of growth and maturity to describe agency as moral, practical reasoning in transitions is remarkably reminiscent of Emerson. 29
